summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The Government responds to the defendant's proposed redactions to pre-trial motions, agreeing with most redactions to protect the integrity of ongoing investigations, victim-witness privacy, and confidential materials.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, who has filed pre-trial motions subject to redaction discussions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this government letter is addressed regarding motion redactions.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who respectfully submits this letter to the court.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.
Audrey Strauss, as United States Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Court Order on Redaction Opportunity
events.description: The Court issued an order providing the Government an opportunity to respond to the defendant's proposed redactions to pre-trial motions.

events.title: Defendant Files Pre-trial Motions
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed her pre-trial motions, which are the subject of the redaction discussions in this letter.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Government agrees with most of Ghislaine Maxwell's proposed redactions to her pre-trial motions to protect the integrity of ongoing investigations and victim-witness privacy.
Specific motions mentioned include motions to dismiss for breach of a non-prosecution agreement, to suppress under the Fourth and Fifth Amendments, and to dismiss counts as time-barred.
The Government notes that certain motions (Motions 5, 8, 9, & 12) required no redactions from the defendant.
Redactions are justified to protect grand jury secrecy, confidential materials under a Protective Order, and privacy interests in sealed civil proceedings.
